statement.text: The Compton wavelength (λ_C) of a particle is the wavelength of a photon whose energy equals the rest mass energy of that particle. It represents the fundamental quantum mechanical length scale associated with a particle, below which pair production and quantum field effects become important. For a particle of mass m, it is given by λ_C = h/(mc) or in reduced form λ̄_C = ℏ/(mc).
statement.formal: λ_C = h/(mc) = 2π ℏ/(mc), or reduced: λ̄_C = ℏ/(mc)

explanation.intuition: The Compton wavelength is the 'size' scale where a particle's quantum wave nature becomes as important as its particle nature. It's the wavelength of the photon that could be created from (or create) the particle's rest mass via E=mc². At distances smaller than λ_C, you can't localize the particle without creating particle-antiparticle pairs.
explanation.key_insight: The Compton wavelength marks the boundary between single-particle quantum mechanics and quantum field theory. For distances Δx < λ_C, the energy uncertainty ΔE ≥ ℏc/Δx exceeds mc², making pair production possible. This is why quantum field theory is necessary for high-energy physics.
explanation.technical_details: The Compton wavelength arises from setting the photon energy E_γ = hc/λ equal to the particle rest mass energy E = mc². There are two common definitions: the standard λ_C = h/(mc) and the reduced λ̄_C = ℏ/(mc) = λ_C/(2π). The reduced form is more natural in quantum field theory calculations. The Compton wavelength is closely related to the Schwarzschild radius - when λ_C = r_s, you reach the Planck mass.
common_misconceptions: Compton wavelength is NOT the physical size of the particle - it's a quantum length scale
It is NOT the de Broglie wavelength - that depends on momentum, while Compton wavelength depends only on rest mass
Below the Compton wavelength, single-particle quantum mechanics BREAKS DOWN - need quantum field theory

definitions_glossary.compton_wavelength: Wavelength λ_C = h/(mc) associated with particle of rest mass m
definitions_glossary.reduced_compton_wavelength: λ̄_C = ℏ/(mc) = λ_C/(2π), more common in quantum field theory
definitions_glossary.compton_scattering: Inelastic scattering of photon by charged particle, discovered by Arthur Compton (1923)
definitions_glossary.pair_production: Creation of particle-antiparticle pair from energy, requires E ≥ 2mc²
definitions_glossary.de_broglie_wavelength: λ_dB = h/p for particle with momentum p, different from Compton wavelength
definitions_glossary.quantum_field_theory: Framework for particles and fields at energies where pair production is possible

from_photon_energy.step_2: Particle rest mass energy: E = mc²
from_photon_energy.interpretation: Wavelength of photon with energy equal to particle's rest mass

from_uncertainty_principle.step_4: When ΔE ~ mc², pair production threshold reached
from_uncertainty_principle.interpretation: Below λ_C, localization energy exceeds rest mass

relationship_to_de_broglie.compton: λ_C = h/(mc) is characteristic scale even at rest
relationship_to_de_broglie.relativistic: For p = mc, λ_dB = λ_C (particle moving at ~c)
relationship_to_de_broglie.distinction: Compton wavelength is intrinsic; de Broglie wavelength depends on motion

standard_compton_wavelength.usage: Historical definition, uses Planck constant h

reduced_compton_wavelength.usage: Common in quantum field theory and particle physics
reduced_compton_wavelength.context: Natural for QFT calculations and angular momentum

for_proton.comparison: Proton Compton wavelength ~1/1836 of electron (mass ratio)

in_quantum_mechanics.localization_limit: Cannot localize particle to Δx < λ_C without pair production
in_quantum_mechanics.quantum_classical_boundary: Particles with λ_C << size behave classically
in_quantum_mechanics.wave_particle_duality: λ_C sets scale where wave and particle aspects equally important

in_quantum_field_theory.pair_production_threshold: At energies E > mc² or distances < λ̄_C, pairs produced
in_quantum_field_theory.effective_field_theory: QFT necessary when probing distances < λ̄_C
in_quantum_field_theory.propagator_structure: Appears in Feynman propagators as characteristic length
in_quantum_field_theory.renormalization: Regulator scale often set by Compton wavelength

in_particle_physics.cross_sections: Particle interaction cross sections σ ~ λ̄_C²
in_particle_physics.decay_rates: Decay widths involve 1/λ̄_C as characteristic energy scale
in_particle_physics.form_factors: Structure measured by comparing distances to λ̄_C
in_particle_physics.experimental_scale: Accelerator energies compared to mc² determine if λ_C matters

in_quantum_gravity.planck_scale_connection: When λ_C = r_s (Schwarzschild radius), m = m_P (Planck mass)
in_quantum_gravity.black_hole_criterion: For m < m_P: λ_C > r_s (quantum dominates)
in_quantum_gravity.for_m_greater_planck: For m > m_P: r_s > λ_C (gravity dominates, black hole forms)
in_quantum_gravity.quantum_gravity_regime: When λ_C ~ r_s ~ ℓ_P, quantum gravity essential

electron_compton_wavelength.comparison_to_atom: Electron Compton wavelength ~5000 times smaller than Bohr radius (53 pm)
electron_compton_wavelength.interpretation: Electron acts as wave on scales larger than 2.4 pm

proton_compton_wavelength.comparison_to_size: Proton radius ~0.84 fm, so λ̄_C,p ~ proton size
proton_compton_wavelength.interpretation: Proton size is comparable to its Compton wavelength - strong quantum effects

planck_mass_compton_wavelength.interpretation: Planck mass is where quantum wavelength equals gravitational radius

thomson_scattering_cross_section.electron_radius: r_e = e²/(4πε_0 m_e c²) = α λ̄_C,e
thomson_scattering_cross_section.interpretation: Photon-electron cross section set by (Compton wavelength)²

scale_comparisons.note: Macroscopic Compton wavelength due to tiny mass

discovery.observation: Scattered photon wavelength shifts by Δλ = (h/m_e c)(1 - cos θ)

historical_context.significance: Compton scattering provided direct evidence for photon particle nature and confirmed λ_C = h/(m_e c) as fundamental length scale

theoretical_development.development: de Broglie proposes matter waves λ = h/p
theoretical_development.connection: Compton wavelength is special case for rest mass

theoretical_development.development: Dirac equation predicts pair production at E > 2m_e c²
theoretical_development.connection: Explains why QFT needed below λ_C
Compton wavelength appears as natural length scale

natural_units.interpretation: In natural units, Compton wavelength is inverse of mass

relativistic_invariance.rest_frame: λ_C = h/(m_0 c) uses rest mass m_0
relativistic_invariance.boosted_frame: Compton wavelength is Lorentz invariant (depends on rest mass)
relativistic_invariance.contrast: de Broglie wavelength λ_dB = h/p is NOT invariant (momentum dependent)

Forgetting factor of 2π between λ_C and λ̄_C
Thinking Compton wavelength is the 'size' of particle
Using wrong mass in calculation (need rest mass)
